description: One-minute skill: Marbury v. Madison and Judicial Review.

hook.text: In 1803, the Supreme Court claimed a power the Constitution never explicitly granted: the power to strike down laws.

buildup.text: Marbury v. Madison established judicial reviewâ€”the court's authority to declare laws unconstitutional.

discovery.text: Chief Justice Marshall reasoned that the Constitution is supreme law, so courts must invalidate conflicting statutes.

twist.text: Marshall actually ruled against his own party's interests. That restraint gave the decision lasting legitimacy.

climax.text: Judicial review became the judiciary's greatest powerâ€”and the most debated feature of American government.

punchline.text: The Court gave itself the last word. America has lived with that ever since.
